statement.text: Hybrid aortic arch repair is a combined surgical and endovascular approach to treating arch pathology, designed to minimize the morbidity of full open arch replacement in high-risk patients. The procedure involves surgical extra-anatomic bypass (debranching) of the supra-aortic vessels (innominate, left carotid, left subclavian arteries) followed by thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR) with stent-graft landing in the arch or ascending aorta. The extent of debranching determines the proximal landing zone achievable, with Zone 0 repair requiring complete arch debranching.
statement.formal: Hybrid Arch Repair: Stage 1 = surgical supra-aortic vessel bypass from ascending aorta (via sternotomy or cervical incisions). Stage 2 = TEVAR with proximal landing in Zone 0-2 depending on debranching extent. May be performed as single-stage or staged procedures.

explanation.intuition: Imagine needing to repair a highway overpass while keeping traffic flowing. One approach is to shut everything down and rebuild (open surgery with circulatory arrest). The hybrid approach is like building bypass roads first (debranching), then repairing the overpass section by section (TEVAR). It's less disruptive overall, though it requires two types of work: road construction and bridge repair.
explanation.key_insight: The fundamental trade-off is between the morbidity of circulatory arrest (avoided in hybrid repair) versus the complexity of creating surgical bypasses plus the risks of endovascular repair (endoleak, retrograde dissection). Patient selection is critical: hybrid repair is most valuable in high-risk patients who would not tolerate full open arch replacement.
explanation.technical_details: Debranching configurations vary based on extent of arch coverage needed. Zone 0 landing (ascending aorta) requires complete debranching of all arch vessels via median sternotomy, typically with a branched graft from the ascending aorta to the innominate, left carotid, and left subclavian arteries. Zone 1 landing requires innominate artery revascularization. Zone 2 landing requires left carotid revascularization. Less extensive debranching can sometimes be performed via cervical incisions (carotid-carotid-subclavian bypasses). TEVAR can be performed simultaneously or staged (days to weeks later).

primary: Aortic arch aneurysm in high surgical risk patients
Type B dissection extending into arch

zone_0.debranching_required: Complete - innominate, left carotid, left subclavian

zone_1.notes: Must preserve left carotid and subclavian

zone_2.location: Between left carotid and left subclavian

complete_debranching_zone_0.graft: Branched Dacron graft from ascending aorta

TEVAR_stage.timing: Immediate (same procedure) or staged (days to weeks)
TEVAR_stage.access: Typically femoral, may require iliac conduit
TEVAR_stage.device_requirements: Proximal diameter, length, conformability to arch curvature
TEVAR_stage.challenges: Arch angulation, delivery around arch, retrograde dissection risk

complications: Spinal cord ischemia (less common than descending TEVAR)

good_candidates: High surgical risk for open arch replacement
poor_candidates: Ascending aortic pathology (aneurysm, dissection involving ascending)
Previous ascending aortic surgery with limited inflow options

definition.@value: Combined surgical bypass of supra-aortic vessels followed by endovascular stent-graft repair of the aortic arch, offering an alternative to full open arch replacement in high-risk patients

sources.citation: Erbel R, et al. 2014 ESC Guidelines on the diagnosis and treatment of aortic diseases. Eur Heart J. 2014;35(41):2873-926.
Moulakakis KG, et al. Hybrid open-endovascular technique for aortic arch pathologies. Ann Cardiothorac Surg. 2013;2(3):284-91.
Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy, 10th Edition, Chapter 78

learning_objectives: Describe the rationale for hybrid arch repair in high-risk patients
Explain the zone classification system for arch landing zones
Correlate debranching extent with achievable landing zone
Compare surgical approaches for complete vs partial debranching
Understand the risks of hybrid repair including retrograde dissection
Select appropriate candidates for hybrid vs open arch repair
clinical_pearls: Zone 0 landing requires complete debranching via sternotomy
Retrograde Type A dissection is a feared complication of TEVAR in the arch
Stroke risk increases with more proximal landing zones
Cervical debranching avoids sternotomy but limits landing to Zone 2+
Connective tissue disorders are relative contraindications due to dissection risk

medicalCode.description: Endovascular repair of descending thoracic aorta
